results.title: Motivation and reward in learning
results.creator_credit: Gardner Hart, Neal E. Miller and Pennsylvania State College Productions
results.brief_description: Records experimental demonstrations with white rats to illustrate the importance of motivation and reward in learning. Compares a hungry, active rat with a saitated, inactive rat. The hungry animal learns to get food by pressing a bar, while the satiated animal goes to sleep. To demonstrate that failure to learn is due to lack of motivation, a mild electric shock is supplied and the satiated animal becomes active and learns to strike a lever which turns off the shock. Shows the animal also learning to rotate a wheel, bite a rubber tube, and strike another animal to avoid electric shock.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gardner Hart, Neal E. Miller and Pennsylvania State College Productions

results.title: Motivation and emotion
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
Motivation is the general term for all the physical and psychological processes that start behaviour, maintain it and stop it. What motivates people to do good … or evil? Psychology professor, Philip Zimbardo, of Stanford University, discusses why we act and feel as we do, exploring the biological and sociological aspects of motivation and its relation to our emotions, as well as the constant tension existing between desire and restraint, particularly in relation to sexual attraction.

results.title: Motivation
results.creator_credit: Ted Boehler and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Why do we do what we do? This program interviews experts in the field who give their opinions as to what motivates us. They include biological influences, extrinsic and intrinsic rewards, reinforcement, cognition or self-esteem and expectancy, and play and curiosity leading to the conclusion that if we understand our motives we have more power to accept or change what we think and what we do.

results.title: Motivating the class
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Educational Psychology”.
Portrays a student-teacher trying to interest a class in the subject of mathematics. His mistakes and achievements are shown with explanatory comments by his supervisory teacher. The students are first taught in an abstract fashion, without relating the subject to the interests of the student. Later, mathematics are applied to subjects of student interest, student participation is encouraged, outdoor projects are undertaken leading to more effective teaching.

results.title: Motivating people in today's workplace
results.brief_description: This is an audiocassette seminar led by Mickey Kinder. How do you get people excited about working - when their work isn’t all that exciting? This is one of the toughest challenges facing managers. Ultimately the organisations success depends on an interested, motivated staff. This audio program describes motivational strategies that get results from inspiring staff from within. Some of the skills you will learn include; motivational strategies for specific situations, including self-directed teams, how to keep spirits high during down-sizing, how to start new employees off on the right foot, and how to recognise the needs of current employees. Looks at motivational theories to explain the types of motivation available and the situations in which they do or do not work.

results.title: Motion study in action
results.creator_credit: Ralph Barnes and University of Iowa
results.brief_description: Shows principles of motion economy applied to many kinds of manual work. Old and new methods are shown for twelve different jobs, including the following: Sorting incoming orders; assembling and attaching buckles on shoes; opening cartons; placing pies in bags and filling glasses with ice and water.

results.title: Motion pictures. 1st 20 years. Part 1: 1898-1903
results.brief_description:
A compilation of silent films from 1898-1903. Films restored from the Library of Congress paper prints.
Contents: Elopement on horseback (1898)—Strange adventure of N.Y. Drummer (1899)—Uncle Josh’s nightmare (1900)—Terrible Teddy, the grizzly king (1901)—Love by the light of the moon (1901)—Panarama of esplanade by night (1901)—Martyred presidents (1901)—Uncle Josh at the moving picture show (1902)—Fun in a bakery shop (1902)—Jack and the beanstalk (1902)— Life of an American fireman (1903)

results.title: Motion pictures produced in Great Britain 1903-1905
results.brief_description:
A compilation of early silent motion pictures produced in Great Britain by Clarendon, Gaumont and Hepworth.
Contents: How this old woman caught the omnibus (1903)—The Eviction (1904)—The Bewitched traveller (1904)—An Englishman’s trip to Paris from London (1904)—The Lover’s ruse (1904)—A Race for a kiss (1904)—The Other side of the hedge (1904)—Fine feathers make fine birds (1905)
Copyrighted by American Mutoscope and Biograph Company - films restored from the Library of Congress paper prints.
